comment_text: Who else finds this unsurprising...?

Just heard about this. Apparently, it says that: however random physical existence is, if a series of events can be given arithmetic values, the number 1 comes up most; then 2 and so on. At first, this sounds like madness. Complete random disorder has a god-like order?
While people can explain the results mathematically as here and it is often applied, for example, in examining financial records to find evidence of fraud, I have not heard a fundamental explanation for it.
Then the reason struck me. Even though I was the biggest dunce at maths at school. Duh.
Every event has energy. Every event has an effect on other events. These generate waves of energy.
So, take any series of waves. They go up and down, passing above and below zero. And what is the most likely number nearest to zero? One. And the next likely value? Two. And so on.. This phenomenon may be described as the heart-beat of physical existence.
That’s the only answer I can come up with that makes any sort of sense. Maybe I should apply that in drawing a number in the Californian Lotto. Yay!
Any other theories?
What do you think about using  Benfords Law to look for problems in Covid19 data?

It is not about the number 1. It is about how the fixed scale relates to random events that we thought were random and raises the question does random really exist when you associate or add Benford to the situation or equation. Seeing it as a clue or evidence is not 100% accurate or false. And that is the confusing part of it. We can use it as a define solution or has a false positive of the conclusion. What you guys are saying in this video as far as using a 2-base system to catch the pattern, this is not how Benford was seeing it when his law came to vision. It seems like you took a complicated theory and added the binary concept to make it clear to you. Not sure what you are trying to say in this video at all. Maybe it is over my head, who knows.

@Wodey25 what

I've got a super easy explanation for this.  1sq, 2sq, 3sq, 4sq is distributed in the same way as 1/1 1/2 1/3 1/4.  Do you see a pattern here?  The number series 1-2-3-4 is the common theme here.  This way of filtering number sets by choosing the 1s, the 2s, the 3s, and the 4s etc and assigning a value to them of 1/1, 1/2, 1/3, 1/4, or in other words reciprocating the numbers, is sort of circular thinking...  It's cool, though.  Not a mystery, though.
@NewgroundsOwnSBB replace the (dot) with . and write the number 1655625 in the url yourself and you won't get the 404.

@alkalait It means the pitches with numbers starting on 1 will be perceived as a wider range of pitches than the pitches with numbers starting on other numbers. But this doesn't mean your brain perceives some pitches differently than others (it does, actually, but not for this reason). It's going to be that way with any unit, like hz, Mhz, Ghz, etc. Hopefully this picture of a spectrum analyzer will give you the right idea. if it doesn't, PM me. Since we perceive sounds on a logarithmic scale (non linearly as you pointed in the previous video), does that mean that our brain samples mostly 10^n type of frequencies on the Decibel version of Benford's distribution?

@SgtRevan Basically the further down the scale you go the more the scale is squished to fit all the numbers. From 1 to 10 its only squished a little (only needs to fit 9 numbers), from 10 to 100 it's squished  more (needs to fit 90 numbers) etc...

Try imagining the scale if it was linear and look at what regions have a '1' as the first digit. The regions will get bigger and bigger as you go down the scale. Now imagine a truck smashing the scale from the right side squishing it into a log scale.
Why did the 1 have such a big chunk on the log scale I'm a little confused...
Do you have a video about logarithmic scales?

My guess would be that the constants are mostly arbitrary, and the person coming up with them would prefer the number to start with a 1 more than any other. The units would have to be altered to accommodate the preferred number. Don't know if this would explain why the difference between the 1's and 9's is so extreme, or why it follows Benford's law, but that's still my best guess. ;-)
